title: Question 226

children: A 76-year-old man is evaluated because of a 1-month history of left shoulder pain that worsens when he brushes his hair or puts on a tee shirt.

On physical examination, there is no tenderness to palpation. There is pain on active and passive abduction between 60 and 120 degrees. Drop arm testing is negative. Pain is reproduced with the empty can test. Range of motion and strength are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Sling immobilization and subacromial glucocorticoid injection

children: Most patients with nontraumatic rotator cuff disease do not require imaging studies; however, when the diagnosis is unclear or if concern exists for a rotator cuff tear, imaging of the shoulder with MRI is the preferred modality.

Initial therapy for rotator cuff tendinopathy typically includes rest, avoidance of aggravating activities, NSAIDs, and physical therapy to strengthen the rotator cuff muscles and improve flexibility.
This patient most likely has rotator cuff tendinopathy (specifically, supraspinatus tendinopathy) and would likely benefit from physical therapy (

). Rotator cuff disease is the most common cause of shoulder pain and refers to all symptomatic rotator cuff disorders, including subacromial bursitis, tendinopathy, and rotator cuff tear. Risk factors for rotator cuff disease include increasing age and participation in activities that require repetitive overhead arm use. This patient has worsened pain with overhead activities, pain with active abduction, and a positive painful arc test (complete passive abduction of arm with pain between 60 and 120 degrees) and empty can test. The empty can test is a maneuver where the extended arm is passively abducted to 90° in the plane of the supraspinatus (30° anterior to the coronal plane) and internally rotated (as though pouring a glass of water onto the floor). The patient is asked to maintain the position while the examiner exerts downward force on the arm. Weakness or reproduction of pain is a positive result. These findings are consistent with rotator cuff tendinopathy involving the supraspinatus tendon, which is the most commonly involved tendon in nontraumatic rotator cuff injury. Given the patient's classic presentation and examination findings, it is appropriate to diagnose him without further testing. Initial therapy typically includes rest, avoidance of aggravating activities, NSAIDs, and physical therapy to strengthen the rotator cuff muscles and improve flexibility.

Most patients with nontraumatic rotator cuff disease do not require imaging studies. However, when the diagnosis is unclear or if concern exists for a rotator cuff tear, imaging of the shoulder should be obtained. MRI is the preferred imaging modality (>90% sensitivity), although ultrasonography (

), in experienced hands, is also an option. This patient has no evidence of a complete rotator cuff tear; his strength is preserved, and he has a negative drop arm test, which argue against a full-thickness tear. Therefore, imaging is unnecessary in this patient.
Neither immobilization with a sling nor subacromial glucocorticoid injections (

) would be appropriate for this patient. Immobilization with a sling should be avoided to prevent development of adhesive capsulitis. Subacromial glucocorticoid injections may provide short-term pain relief in patients with subacromial bursitis in whom other measures have failed but should be limited to one or two courses to limit complications.

references: Whittle S, Buchbinder R. In the clinic. Rotator cuff disease.
